subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... My impression was that it was meant to be a bit more than that--a better way to write English. But even if it is a practical shorthand, it is a shorthand
messageBody:
Michael Everson wrote:
>
>
> At 18:22 -0400 2007-10-30, Paul Tremblay wrote:
>
> >Is QS to mean anything or is it just a plaything?
>
> It's meant to be a practical shorthand.
> --

My impression was that it was meant to be a bit more than that--a better
way to write English.

But even if it is a practical shorthand, it is a shorthand based on the
40 sounds of the English language. That was how it was devised, right?
These 40 sounds can be mapped to the IPA. Using the IPA is a very
precise way to describe the sounds. Saying that "Awl" (or "Awe") is
pronounced like "haul" is very imprecise since people pronounce "haul"
differently.

As I said, an alphabet either has to represent words (as English has
come to do with its standardized, non phonetical spelling), or it has to
represent sounds. If it represents neither, then it is completely
meaningless and cannot be used to communicate with other people. If it
represents neither, then theoritically I can spell "ball" with
"Pipe-Eight-Mime."

I cannot see any good argument against a mapping of QS to IPA. I know
that the mapping would not be precise as the IPA itself. For example,
"Ado" can be pronounced as two IPA symbols, one stressed and one
unstressed. But then it is a simple matter of pointing this out.

Paul
